Save the Rocky Mountain Tree Trout

Elusive. Arboreal. Surprisingly good at climbing. The Rocky Mountain Tree Trout depends on our forests for habitat and our voices for protection.

Donate or Get Involved

Origin & Range

First documented in 1907 by backcountry mycologists, the Tree Trout (Oncorhynchus arboris) is native to high-elevation spruce and fir stands throughout the central Rockies. Sightings peak between $2{,}500$–$3{,}300$ meters where fog drip sustains canopy pools.

Qualities

Adapted for arboreal life: prehensile pectoral fins, bark-mimicking patterning, and a remarkable ability to "leap-ladder" boughs during seasonal migrations.

History & Status

Logging, climate shifts, and the decline of epiphytic moss pools have fragmented habitat. The Tree Trout is currently listed as "cryptically threatened", pending further study.

Forest Impact

As a keystone detritivore, Tree Trout regulate canopy invertebrates and redistribute nutrients from canopy pools to understory soils via seasonal descents.

Evolution

Phylogenetic models suggest a divergence from stream trout during a pluvial period, with subsequent selection for vertical niche exploration driven by fog drip hydrology.

Relations

Co-occurs with canopy salamanders, gliding squirrels, and the lesser pine moth. Symbiotic relationships include mutualistic moss grooming and seed dispersal (accidental).

How We’re Different

Unlike other conservation sites, we emphasize canopy hydrology, citizen science, and forest-compatible folklore. Our approach blends rigorous field notes with joyful curiosity.
